article.title: Cajal body
article.text:
[[Image:Cajal bodies.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Image of four oval-shaped blue nuclei containing small green dots representing Cajal bodies. |Nuclei of mouse cells (blue) containing Cajal bodies (green) visualized by fusion of p80/Coilin protein to GFP.]]
'''Cajal bodies''' (CBs)  also '''coiled bodies''', are spherical sub-organelles of 0.3-1.0 µm in diameter found in the [[cell nucleus|nucleus]] of proliferative [[cell (biology)|cell]]s like [[embryonic cell]]s and [[tumor cell]]s, or metabolically active cells like [[neuron]]s. In contrast to cytoplasmic [[organelle]]s, CBs lack any phospholipid membrane which would separate their content, largely consisting of proteins and RNA, from the surrounding [[nucleoplasm]]. They were first reported by [[Santiago Ramón y Cajal]] in 1903, who called them ''nucleolar accessory bodies'' due to their association with the [[Nucleolus|nucleoli]] in neuronal cells.<ref name=Cajal_1903>{{cite journal |author=Cajal SR |title=Un sencillo metodo de coloracion selectiva del reticulo protoplasmico y sus efectos en los diversos organos nerviosos de vertebrados e invertebrados |journal=Trab Lab Investig Biol Univ Madr |volume=2 |issue= |pages=129–221 |year=1903 |pmid= |doi=}}</ref> They were rediscovered with the use of the [[electron microscope]] (EM) and named ''coiled bodies'', according to their appearance as coiled threads on EM images, and later renamed after their discoverer.<ref name="Gall">{{cite journal|last1=Gall|first1=JG|last2=Bellini|first2=M|last3=Wu|first3=Z|last4=Murphy|first4=C|title=Assembly of the nuclear transcription and processing machinery: Cajal bodies (coiled bodies) and transcriptosomes.|journal=Molecular Biology of the Cell|date=December 1999|volume=10|issue=12|pages=4385–402|pmid=10588665|doi=10.1091/mbc.10.12.4385|pmc=25765}}</ref> Research on CBs was accelerated after discovery and [[Molecular cloning|cloning]] of the marker protein [[Coilin|p80/Coilin]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Andrade LE, Chan EK, Raska I, Peebles CL, Roos G, Tan EM |title=Human autoantibody to a novel protein of the nuclear coiled body: immunological characterization and cDNA cloning of p80-coilin |journal=J. Exp. Med. |volume=173 |issue=6 |pages=1407–19 |date=June 1991 |pmid=2033369 |pmc=2190846 |doi= 10.1084/jem.173.6.1407|url=}}</ref> CBs have been implicated in RNA-related metabolic processes such as [[snRNP]]s biogenesis, maturation and recycling, [[histone]] mRNA processing and telomere maintenance. CBs assemble RNA which is used by telomerase to add nucleotides to the ends of telomeres.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Wright, W.E.|first=Zhao, Y.|author2=Abreu, E.|author3=Kim, J.|author4=Stadler, G.|author5=Eskiocak, U.|author6=Terns, M.P.|author7=Terns, R.M.|author8=Shay, J.W.|title=Processive and Distributive Extension of Human Telomeres by Telomerase Under Homeostatic and Non-equilibrium Conditions|journal=Molecular Cell|date=6 May 2011|volume=42|issue=3|pages=297–307 |doi=10.1016/j.molcel.2011.03.020 |url=http://www.cell.com/molecular-cell/abstract/S1097-2765(11)00248-6|pmid=21549308|pmc=3108241}}</ref>

==History==
CBs were initially discovered by neurobiologist [[Santiago Ramón y Cajal]] in 1903 as small argyrophilic spots in nuclei of silver-stained neuronal cells. Because of their close association with nucleoli he named them ''nucleolar accessory bodies''. Later on, they were forgotten and rediscovered multiple times independently which led to a state where scientists from different research fields used different names for the same structure. Names used for CBs included "sphere organelles", "Binnenkörper", "nucleolar bodies" or "coiled bodies". The name coiled bodies comes from observation of electron microscopists Monneron and Bernhard. They described  bodies as aggregates composed of coiled threads with thickness of 400-600 [[Ångström|Å]]. When using higher magnification, they appear as tiny, 50 Å thick fibrils irregularly twisted along the axis of the threads. The bodies were even predicted to consist of [[ribonucleoproteins]] since treatment of cells with [[protease]] and [[RNase]] together, but not alone, caused dramatic changes to the structure of CBs.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Monneron A, Bernhard W |title=Fine structural organization of the interphase nucleus in some mammalian cells |journal=J. Ultrastruct. Res. |volume=27 |issue=3 |pages=266–88 |date=May 1969 |pmid=5813971 |doi= 10.1016/S0022-5320(69)80017-1|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/B7MF7-4DR1MH6-14/2/6b749ce5733da01790d4ff0ca5ef3c3a}}</ref>

==Localization==
Cajal bodies are only found in nuclei of plant, yeast, and animal cells.<ref name="CioceLamond2005">{{cite journal|last1=Cioce|first1=Mario|last2=Lamond|first2=Angus I.|title=CAJAL BODIES: A Long History of Discovery|journal=Annual Review of Cell and Developmental Biology|volume=21|issue=1|year=2005|pages=105–131|issn=1081-0706|doi=10.1146/annurev.cellbio.20.010403.103738|pmid=16212489}}</ref>
The cells in which Cajal bodies are most apparent usually demonstrate high levels of transcriptional activity, and are often dividing rapidly.<ref name=Ogg_2002>{{cite journal |vauthors=Ogg SC, Lamond A |title=Cajal bodies and coilin—moving towards function |journal=J Cell Biol |volume=159 |issue=1 |pages=17–21 |year=2002 |pmid=12379800 |doi=10.1083/jcb.200206111 |pmc=2173504}}</ref>

==CBs and cell cycle==
They are about 0.1-2.0 [[micrometre]]s and are found one to five per nucleus. The number varies in different types of cells and over the cell cycle. Maximum number is reached in mid G<sub>1</sub> phase and towards G<sub>2</sub> they become larger and their number decreases. CBs disassemble during the M phase and reappear again later in G<sub>1</sub> phase. Cajal bodies are possibly sites of assembly or modification of the [[transcription (genetics)|transcription]] machinery of the nucleus.<ref name=Cremer_2001>{{cite journal |vauthors=Cremer T, Cremer C |title=Chromosome territories, nuclear architecture and gene regulation in mammalian cells |journal=Nat Rev Genet |volume=2 |issue=4 |pages=292–301 |year=2001 |pmid=11283701 |doi=10.1038/35066075}}</ref>

==Functions==
CBs are bound to the [[nucleolus]] by [[coilin]] proteins. P80-coilin is a specific marker for coiled bodies,<ref name="pmid2088441">{{cite journal | author = Raska I | title = Association between the nucleolus and the coiled body | journal = J. Struct. Biol. | volume = 104 | issue = 1–3 | pages = 120–7 | year = 1990 | pmid = 2088441 | doi =10.1016/1047-8477(90)90066-L |name-list-format=vanc| author2 = Ochs RL | author3 = Andrade LE | display-authors = 3 | last4 = Chan | first4 = E.K.L. | last5 = Burlingame | first5 = R. | last6 = Peebles | first6 = C. | last7 = Gruol | first7 = D. | last8 = Tan | first8 = E.M. }}</ref> and demonstrates these bodies tend to be associated with the nucleolus when cells are not dividing. Cajal bodies are associated with telomerase assembly and recruitment via a CAB-RNA sequence common in both CB RNAs (scaRNAs) and the RNA component of telomerase (TERC). TCAB1 recognizes the CAB sequence in both and recruits telomerase to the CBs.

CBs contain high concentrations of [[RNA splicing|splicing]] small nuclear ribonucleoproteins ([[snRNP]]s), possibly indicating that they function to modify RNA after it has been [[Translation (biology)|transcribed]] from DNA.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Nizami Z, Deryusheva S, Gall JG | title=The Cajal body and histone locus body | journal=COLD SPRING HARBOR PERSPECTIVES IN BIOLOGY | volume=2 | issue=7 | year=2010 | pages=a000653 | url = http://cshperspectives.cshlp.org/content/2/7/a000653.long | pmc = 2890199 | doi = 10.1101/cshperspect.a000653 | id= | pmid=20504965}}</ref> Experimental evidence indicates that CBs contribute to the [[biogenesis]] of [[telomerase]] enzyme, and assist in subsequent transport of telomerase to [[telomere]]s.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Jády BE, Richard P, Bertrand E, Kiss T | title=Cell cycle-dependent recruitment of telomerase RNA and Cajal bodies to human telomeres | journal=[[Molecular Biology of the Cell]] | volume=17 | issue=2 | year=2006 | pages=944–954 | url = http://www.molbiolcell.org/content/17/2/944.long | pmc = 1356602 | id= | pmid=16319170 | doi=10.1091/mbc.E05-09-0904}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Tomlinson RL, Ziegler TD, Supakorndej T, Terns RM, Terns MP | title=Cell cycle-regulated trafficking of human telomerase to telomeres | journal=[[Molecular Biology of the Cell]] | volume=17 | issue=2 | year=2006 | pages=955–965 | url = http://www.molbiolcell.org/content/17/2/955.long | pmc = 1356603 | id= | pmid=16339074 | doi=10.1091/mbc.E05-09-0903}}</ref>
